reasoning: The critique targets an ambiguity in the paper’s illustrative benchmark (“Common-sense utopia”): the description stipulates “minimal suffering among nonhuman animals and non-biological beings,” which does partially pre-solve at least one major example the paper later uses (animal suffering) and arguably softens the setup for digital-welfare worries. However, this is not a highly load-bearing premise for the paper’s main thesis (“no easy eutopia”): the central argument is that many distinct, non-obvious moral dimensions can go wrong and that many plausible value functions are ‘fussy’; this does not depend heavily on that particular vignette being a default outcome. The critique also overstates its case by implying the stipulation resolves ‘several’ later-identified hard problems; many of the later failure modes (population ethics, scale, rights/ownership/justice for digital beings, value theory divergences, allocation, etc.) are not settled merely by “minimal suffering.” Still, it is a real (though patchable) presentational tension that weakens the rhetorical force of the “eutopia seems easy” intuition pump. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Common-sense utopia smuggles in solutions to the hard problems it later identifies
